page.title: Timeline of the 2011 Egyptian revolution under Supreme Council of the Armed Forces

rev.diff:
Line 151: Line 151:
On 14 July, Mubarak told prosecutors that he did not order security forces to open fire on protesters during the initial uprising in February. Transcripts of prosecutors questioning Mubarak were published in two Egyptian newspapers{{Which?|date=July 2011}}, and judicial officials confirmed the authenticity of the documents.<ref name="voanews1">{{cite web|url=http://www.voanews.com/english/news/middle-east/Egyptian-Media-Mubarak-Denies-Ordering-Police-to-Fire-on-Protesters-125577073.html |title=Egyptian Media: Mubarak Denies Ordering Police to Fire on Protesters | Middle East | English |publisher=Voanews.com |date=2011-07-14 |accessdate=2011-07-19}}</ref> Mubarak said he issued clear instructions for police not to use force against the protesters. He also denied charges that he ordered or had knowledge of security forces firing on the demonstrators.<ref name="voanews1"/>
On 14 July, Mubarak told prosecutors that he did not order security forces to open fire on protesters during the initial uprising in February. Transcripts of prosecutors questioning Mubarak were published in two Egyptian newspapers{{Which?|date=July 2011}}, and judicial officials confirmed the authenticity of the documents.<ref name="voanews1">{{cite web|url=http://www.voanews.com/english/news/middle-east/Egyptian-Media-Mubarak-Denies-Ordering-Police-to-Fire-on-Protesters-125577073.html |title=Egyptian Media: Mubarak Denies Ordering Police to Fire on Protesters | Middle East | English |publisher=Voanews.com |date=2011-07-14 |accessdate=2011-07-19}}</ref> Mubarak said he issued clear instructions for police not to use force against the protesters. He also denied charges that he ordered or had knowledge of security forces firing on the demonstrators.<ref name="voanews1"/>
â
On 16 July, Maj. Gen. Tarek el-Mahdi briefly visited a protest camp in Tahrir Square but left after protesters, some holding shoes in anger, booed him off a stage. He had come to persuade a dozen demonstrators to end a hunger strike which had begun several days ago. El-Mahdi later told state television that he was disappointed that a small crowd of protesters managed to drive him out of the square before he could reach the tent housing the hunger strikers.<ref>{{cite web|last=Deeb |first=Sarah El |url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/43780050/ns/world_news-mideast_n_africa/ |title=Senior Egyptian military official heckled - World news - Mideast/N. Africa - msnbc.com |publisher=MSNBC |date= |accessdate=2011-07-19}}</ref> Prime Minister Essam Sharaf also accepted the resignation of Foreign Minister Mohammed el-Orabi. He then appointed two new deputies, one of which was prominent economist and former head of the U.N. Economic and Social Commission for Western Asia, Hazem el-Biblawi.<ref>{{cite web|last=Deeb |first=Sarah El |url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/43780050/ns/world_news-mideast_n_africa/ |title=Senior Egyptian military official heckled - World news - Mideast/N. Africa - msnbc.com |publisher=MSNBC |date= |accessdate=2011-07-19}}</ref>
+
On 16 July, Maj. Gen. Tarek el-Mahdi briefly visited a protest camp in Tahrir Square but left after protesters, some holding shoes in anger, booed him off a stage. He had come to persuade a dozen demonstrators to end a hunger strike which had begun several days ago. El-Mahdi later told state television that he was disappointed that a small crowd of protesters managed to drive him out of the square before he could reach the tent housing the hunger strikers.<ref name="autogenerated1">{{cite web|last=Deeb |first=Sarah El |url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/43780050/ns/world_news-mideast_n_africa/ |title=Senior Egyptian military official heckled - World news - Mideast/N. Africa - msnbc.com |publisher=MSNBC |date= |accessdate=2011-07-19}}</ref> Prime Minister Essam Sharaf also accepted the resignation of Foreign Minister Mohammed el-Orabi. He then appointed two new deputies, one of which was prominent economist and former head of the U.N. Economic and Social Commission for Western Asia, Hazem el-Biblawi.<ref name="autogenerated1"/>
On 17 July, Sharaf named 12 new Cabinet members. State television dubbed the new government lineup the "Revolution Cabinet." Most of the ministers were newcomers as the government sought to placate further criticism by the protesters. Despite the cabinet reshuffle, many of the protesters said that they had no intention of calling off their week-old sit-in.<ref name="sfgate1">{{cite web|author=By SARAH EL DEEB, Associated Press |url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/n/a/2011/07/17/international/i085051D98.DTL |title=Egypt military rulers name electoral council head |publisher=Sfgate.com |date= |accessdate=2011-07-19}}</ref> One of the prominent{{Or|date=July 2011}} members of the "Revolution Cabinet" is the Chief of Antiquities [[Zahi Hawass]]. Hawass is a prominant member of Egypts archaeological community, but has been the target of protests himself. These protests were begun by archaeology students who accused him of falsely claiming publicity for himself and corruption.
On 17 July, Sharaf named 12 new Cabinet members. State television dubbed the new government lineup the "Revolution Cabinet." Most of the ministers were newcomers as the government sought to placate further criticism by the protesters. Despite the cabinet reshuffle, many of the protesters said that they had no intention of calling off their week-old sit-in.<ref name="sfgate1">{{cite web|author=By SARAH EL DEEB, Associated Press |url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/n/a/2011/07/17/international/i085051D98.DTL |title=Egypt military rulers name electoral council head |publisher=Sfgate.com |date= |accessdate=2011-07-19}}</ref> One of the prominent{{Or|date=July 2011}} members of the "Revolution Cabinet" is the Chief of Antiquities [[Zahi Hawass]]. Hawass is a prominant member of Egypts archaeological community, but has been the target of protests himself. These protests were begun by archaeology students who accused him of falsely claiming publicity for himself and corruption.
Sharaf also accepted the resignation of Finance Minister Samir Radwan (the reason for his resignation was due to the fact that his new budget was deemed by many protestors to be too conservative in dealing with the poverty which had been one of the main catalysts of the uprising) and the foreign minister, who was replaced by the former ambassador to Saudia Arabia, Mohammed Kamel Omar. Radwan's position was taken by prominent economist Hazem el-Biblawi, who had also been appointed deputy prime minister. There were also changes in the ministries of transport, military production, higher education, communication, agriculture, health, religious endowments, local development, trade and industry and civil aviation, with ministers being replaced.<ref name="sfgate1"/>
Sharaf also accepted the resignation of Finance Minister Samir Radwan (the reason for his resignation was due to the fact that his new budget was deemed by many protestors to be too conservative in dealing with the poverty which had been one of the main catalysts of the uprising) and the foreign minister, who was replaced by the former ambassador to Saudia Arabia, Mohammed Kamel Omar. Radwan's position was taken by prominent economist Hazem el-Biblawi, who had also been appointed deputy prime minister. There were also changes in the ministries of transport, military production, higher education, communication, agriculture, health, religious endowments, local development, trade and industry and civil aviation, with ministers being replaced.<ref name="sfgate1"/>
â
On 21 July, the SCAF announced that it would bar foreign monitors in the upcoming [[Egyptian parliamentary election, 2011|parliamentary election]] because of what it claimed was the preservation of Egyptian sovereingty<Ref>http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/07/2011720222415556480.html</ref>.
+
On 21 July, the SCAF announced that it would bar foreign monitors in the upcoming [[Egyptian parliamentary election, 2011|parliamentary election]] because of what it claimed was the preservation of Egyptian sovereingty.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/07/2011720222415556480.html |title=Egypt not to allow foreign poll monitors - Middle East |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date= |accessdate=2011-07-24}}</ref>
â
On 23 July, Thousands of protesters tried to march to the [[Egyptian Army#Structure|Defense Ministry]] of Egypt in [[Cairo]] when they were attacked by groups of men wielding knives, sticks, , stones and [[Molotov cocktail|molotov cocktails]]<ref>http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/jul/24/egypt-protest-march-military-council</ref><ref>http://af.reuters.com/article/topNews/idAFJOE76N01L20110724?sp=true</ref>. It was the second time in two days that crowds had tried to march to the headquarters<ref>http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-14265772</ref> located in [[Heliopolis]]. The march started from Tahrir Square making until it was stopped in the eastern Abbasiya neighbourhood by army barricades<ref>http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/jul/24/egypt-protest-march-military-council</ref>. The march was a reaction to the SCAF accused [[6 April Youth Movement]]<ref>http://english.ahram.org.eg/~/NewsContent/1/64/17141/Egypt/Politics-/Thousands-start-marching-from-Tahrir-heading-to-mi.aspx</ref> and [[Kefaya]]<ref>http://bikyamasr.com/wordpress/?p=37180</ref> of treason and that their movements are harming "national interests" a day earlier.
+
On 23 July, Thousands of protesters tried to march to the [[Egyptian Army#Structure|Defense Ministry]] of Egypt in [[Cairo]] when they were attacked by groups of men wielding knives, sticks, , stones and [[Molotov cocktail|molotov cocktails]].<ref name="guardian1">{{cite web|author=Associated Press |url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/jul/24/egypt-protest-march-military-council |title=Egyptian protest march descends into violent clashes | World news | guardian.co.uk |publisher=Guardian |date= |accessdate=2011-07-24}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://af.reuters.com/article/topNews/idAFJOE76N01L20110724?sp=true |title=Scores hurt in clashes, Egypt rulers promise democracy | Top News | Reuters |publisher=Af.reuters.com |date=2009-02-09 |accessdate=2011-07-24}}</ref> It was the second time in two days that crowds had tried to march to the headquarters<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-14265772 |title=BBC News - Clashes at Egypt demonstrations for political change |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date=2011-03-19 |accessdate=2011-07-24}}</ref> located in [[Heliopolis]]. The march started from Tahrir Square making until it was stopped in the eastern Abbasiya neighbourhood by army barricades.<ref name="guardian1"/> The march was a reaction to the SCAF accused [[6 April Youth Movement]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/~/NewsContent/1/64/17141/Egypt/Politics-/Thousands-start-marching-from-Tahrir-heading-to-mi.aspx |title=Thousands start marching from Egypt's Tahrir heading to military council HQ - Politics - Egypt - Ahram Online |publisher=English.ahram.org.eg |date= |accessdate=2011-07-24}}</ref> and [[Kefaya]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://bikyamasr.com/wordpress/?p=37180 |title=Egypt burning: Abbassiya march erupts in violence |publisher=Bikya Masr |date= |accessdate=2011-07-24}}</ref> of treason and that their movements are harming "national interests" a day earlier.
